transcript:
Therapist: You're right, Noor. Building that habit of challenging negative thoughts takes time and practice. Another helpful technique we can use is called the "downward arrow" technique. This helps us uncover the deeper beliefs that might be fueling those automatic thoughts. Would you be willing to try this with me?

Patient: Sure, I'm open to trying new techniques. How does the downward arrow technique work?

Therapist: Great! The downward arrow technique involves asking yourself a series of questions to get to the core belief underlying your automatic thoughts. We start with an automatic thought, like the one you mentioned earlier: "If I don't do this perfectly, the client will be disappointed and won't want to work with me again." Then, we ask ourselves, "If that were true, what would that mean about me or my life?"

Patient: Okay, I think I understand. So, if that thought were true, and the client didn't want to work with me again because I didn't do something perfectly, I guess it would mean that I'm not good enough at my job.

Therapist: Alright, let's keep going. If you're not good enough at your job, what would that mean about you?

Patient: It would mean that I'm a failure, and that I can't live up to my own or others' expectations.

Therapist: I can see how painful that belief must be, Noor. If you're a failure and can't live up to expectations, what does that mean about your life in general?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not worthy of love, respect, or happiness. That I don't deserve good things because I'm not perfect.

Therapist: Thank you for being so open and vulnerable, Noor. I can see how much these beliefs are impacting you. What we've uncovered here is what we call a "core belief." Core beliefs are deeply held beliefs about ourselves, others, and the world that often develop early in life and can be difficult to change. In this case, your core belief seems to be something like, "I'm not good enough, and I don't deserve love, respect, or happiness unless I'm perfect."

Patient: Wow, hearing it said out loud like that really hits me hard. I guess I didn't realize how much I was holding onto that belief.

Therapist: That's very common, Noor. Core beliefs often operate in the background, influencing our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors without us even realizing it. The good news is that we can work on challenging and changing these core beliefs, just like we've been doing with your automatic thoughts.

Patient: That sounds like a lot of work, but I'm willing to try. How do we start challenging these core beliefs?

Therapist: One way to start is by looking for evidence that contradicts the core belief. For example, can you think of any times in your life when you weren't perfect, but you still felt loved, respected, or happy?

Patient: Well, I guess there have been times when I've made mistakes or didn't meet my own expectations, but my friends and family still supported me and showed me love. And there have been moments when I felt happy, even if everything wasn't perfect.

Therapist: That's great, Noor! Those examples are evidence that your core belief isn't 100% true. Another way to challenge core beliefs is to act in ways that are opposite to what the belief tells you. For example, you could intentionally do something imperfectly and see what happens. How does that feel for you?

Patient: It feels scary, but I can see how it might be helpful. Like, maybe I could try sharing something I've worked on with a friend or colleague before it's "perfect" and see if they still appreciate it or find value in it.

Therapist: That's a great idea, Noor! Experimenting with acting opposite to your core belief can help you gather more evidence that the belief isn't true and start to build new, more adaptive beliefs. Remember, challenging core beliefs takes time and practice, so be patient and compassionate with yourself throughout the process.

Patient: I'll try to keep that in mind. It's just hard sometimes, when those negative thoughts and beliefs feel so strong and automatic.

Therapist: I completely understand, Noor. That's why we practice these skills regularly, so that over time, they become more automatic than the negative thoughts and beliefs. Another helpful tool is to create a "positive data log," where you write down evidence that contradicts your negative core beliefs. This can help you start to build new, more balanced beliefs about yourself.

Patient: I like the idea of a positive data log. I think that could help me focus more on the good things, instead of always getting stuck on the negative.

Therapist: Absolutely, Noor! A positive data log can be a powerful tool for shifting your focus and building more balanced, adaptive beliefs. Why don't we practice that now? Can you think of a recent situation where you could challenge your negative core belief and find evidence for a more positive belief?

Patient: Let me think... Well, last week, I had dinner with some friends, and I was feeling really down about myself beforehand. But during the dinner, we had some great conversations, and my friends were really supportive and encouraging. They even complimented me on some recent work I had shared with them.

Therapist: That's a perfect example, Noor! In your positive data log, you could write down that experience as evidence that you are loved and respected, even when you're not feeling perfect. What would be a more balanced, adaptive belief to replace your negative core belief?

Patient: I guess a more balanced belief would be something like, "I am worthy of love, respect, and happiness, even when I'm not perfect. My value doesn't depend on meeting unrealistic expectations."

Therapist: That's a wonderful alternative belief, Noor! As you continue to gather evidence for this new belief in your positive data log, it will start to feel more natural and automatic. And remember, you don't have to do this work alone. Your friends, family, and I are here to support you and remind you of your worth, even when you're struggling to see it yourself.

Patient: Thank you, that means a lot to me. I know it won't be easy, but I'm committed to working on challenging these negative beliefs and building a more balanced, compassionate view of myself.

Therapist: I'm so glad to hear that, Noor. Your commitment and willingness to do this work are huge strengths, and I'm confident that you'll make progress over time. Remember to be patient and kind with yourself throughout the process, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it.

Patient: I'll do my best. Thank you for all your help and guidance.
